commands.help:
Usage: heroku dashboard

display information about favorite apps

Usage: heroku apps:create [APP] [flags]

creates a new app

APP  name of app to create

Flags:
 -b, --buildpack BUILDPACK  buildpack url to use for this app
 -n, --no-remote            do not create a git remote
 -o, --org ORG              team to use
 -r, --remote REMOTE        the git remote to create, default "heroku"
 -s, --stack STACK          the stack to create the app on
 -t, --team TEAM            team to use
 --addons ADDONS            comma-delimited list of addons to install
 --json                     output in json format
 --region REGION            specify region for the app to run in
 --space SPACE              the private space to create the app in
 --ssh-git                  use SSH git protocol for local git remote

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:create
    Creating app... done, stack is cedar-14
    https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

    # or just
    $ heroku create

    # specify a buildpack
    $ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

    # specify a name
    $ heroku apps:create example

    # create a staging app
    $ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

    # create an app in the eu region
    $ heroku apps:create --region eu

Usage: heroku create [APP] [flags]

creates a new app

APP  name of app to create

Flags:
 -b, --buildpack BUILDPACK  buildpack url to use for this app
 -n, --no-remote            do not create a git remote
 -o, --org ORG              team to use
 -r, --remote REMOTE        the git remote to create, default "heroku"
 -s, --stack STACK          the stack to create the app on
 -t, --team TEAM            team to use
 --addons ADDONS            comma-delimited list of addons to install
 --json                     output in json format
 --region REGION            specify region for the app to run in
 --space SPACE              the private space to create the app in
 --ssh-git                  use SSH git protocol for local git remote

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:create
    Creating app... done, stack is cedar-14
    https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

    # or just
    $ heroku create

    # specify a buildpack
    $ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

    # specify a name
    $ heroku apps:create example

    # create a staging app
    $ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

    # create an app in the eu region
    $ heroku apps:create --region eu

Usage: heroku apps:destroy [APP] [flags]

permanently destroy an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP          app to run command against
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -r, --remote REMOTE    git remote of app to use

This will also destroy all add-ons on the app.

Usage: heroku destroy [APP] [flags]

permanently destroy an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP          app to run command against
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -r, --remote REMOTE    git remote of app to use

This will also destroy all add-ons on the app.

Usage: heroku apps:delete [APP] [flags]

permanently destroy an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP          app to run command against
 -c, --confirm CONFIRM
 -r, --remote REMOTE    git remote of app to use

This will also destroy all add-ons on the app.

Usage: heroku apps:errors [flags]

view app errors

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --dyno               show only dyno errors
 --hours HOURS        number of hours to look back (default 24)
 --json               output in json format
 --router             show only router errors

Usage: heroku apps [flags]

list your apps

Flags:
 -A, --all          include apps in all teams
 -o, --org ORG      team to use
 -p, --personal     list apps in personal account when a default team is set
 -s, --space SPACE  filter by space
 -t, --team TEAM    team to use
 --json             output in json format

Usage: heroku list [flags]

list your apps

Flags:
 -A, --all          include apps in all teams
 -o, --org ORG      team to use
 -p, --personal     list apps in personal account when a default team is set
 -s, --space SPACE  filter by space
 -t, --team TEAM    team to use
 --json             output in json format

Usage: heroku apps:list [flags]

list your apps

Flags:
 -A, --all          include apps in all teams
 -o, --org ORG      team to use
 -p, --personal     list apps in personal account when a default team is set
 -s, --space SPACE  filter by space
 -t, --team TEAM    team to use
 --json             output in json format

Usage: heroku apps:info [APP] [flags]

show detailed app information

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -j, --json
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 -s, --shell          output more shell friendly key/value pairs

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:info
    === example
    Git URL:   https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    Repo Size: 5M
    ...

    $ heroku apps:info --shell
    git_url=https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    repo_size=5000000
    ...

Usage: heroku info [APP] [flags]

show detailed app information

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -j, --json
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 -s, --shell          output more shell friendly key/value pairs

Examples:

    $ heroku apps:info
    === example
    Git URL:   https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    Repo Size: 5M
    ...

    $ heroku apps:info --shell
    git_url=https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    repo_size=5000000
    ...

commands.description: open the app in a web browser
commands.help:
Usage: heroku apps:open [PATH] [flags]

open the app in a web browser

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Examples:

    $ heroku open -a myapp
    # opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com

    $ heroku open -a myapp /foo
    # opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com/foo
helpLine: open the app in a web browser

commands.description: open the app in a web browser
commands.help:
Usage: heroku open [PATH] [flags]

Flags:

Examples:

    $ heroku open -a myapp
    # opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com

    $ heroku open -a myapp /foo
    # opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com/foo
helpLine: open the app in a web browser

commands.help:
Usage: heroku apps:rename NEWNAME [flags]

rename an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --ssh-git            use ssh git protocol instead of https

This will locally update the git remote if it is set to the old app.

Example:

    $ heroku apps:rename --app oldname newname
    https://newname.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/newname.git
    Git remote heroku updated

Usage: heroku rename NEWNAME [flags]

rename an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --ssh-git            use ssh git protocol instead of https

This will locally update the git remote if it is set to the old app.

Example:

    $ heroku apps:rename --app oldname newname
    https://newname.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/newname.git
    Git remote heroku updated

Usage: heroku apps:favorites:add [flags]

favorites an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Usage: heroku apps:favorites [flags]

list favorited apps

Flags:
 --json  output in json format

Usage: heroku apps:favorites:remove [flags]

unfavorites an app

Flags:

 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

commands.description: set the stack of an app
commands.help:
Usage: heroku apps:stacks:set STACK [flags]

set the stack of an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Example:

    $ heroku stack:set cedar-14 -a myapp
    Stack set. Next release on myapp will use cedar-14.
    Run git push heroku master to create a new release on myapp.
helpLine: set the stack of an app

commands.description: set the stack of an app
commands.help:

commands.help:
Usage: heroku auth:login [flags]

login with your Heroku credentials

Aliases:
  $ heroku login

Flags:
 -e, --expires-in EXPIRES-IN  duration of token in seconds (default 1 year)
 --browser                    browser to open SSO with
 --sso                        login for enterprise users under SSO

Usage: heroku auth:logout

clears local login credentials

Usage: heroku logout

clears local login credentials

Usage: heroku auth:token

display the current auth token

Usage: heroku auth:2fa:disable

disable 2fa on account

Usage: heroku 2fa:disable

disable 2fa on account

Usage: heroku twofactor:disable

disable 2fa on account

Usage: heroku auth:2fa:generate

generates and replaces recovery codes

Usage: heroku 2fa:generate-recovery-codes

generates and replaces recovery codes

Usage: heroku twofactor:generate-recovery-codes

generates and replaces recovery codes

commands.description: add new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary
commands.help:
Usage: heroku buildpacks:add URL [flags]

add new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -i, --index INDEX    the 1-based index of the URL in the list of URLs
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Example:

     $ heroku buildpacks:add -i 1 https://github.com/heroku/heroku-buildpack-ruby
helpLine: add new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary

commands.description: clear all buildpacks set on the app
commands.help:

commands.description: remove a buildpack set on the app
commands.help:

remove a buildpack set on the app

                      URLs
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

commands.description: set new app buildpack, overwriting into list of buildpacks if necessary
commands.help:
Usage: heroku buildpacks:set URL [flags]

set new app buildpack, overwriting into list of buildpacks if necessary

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -i, --index INDEX    the 1-based index of the URL in the list of URLs
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Example:

     $ heroku buildpacks:set -i 1 heroku/ruby
helpLine: set new app buildpack, overwriting into list of buildpacks if necessary

commands.description: display a config value for an app
commands.help:
Usage: heroku config:get KEY [flags]

display a config value for an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 -s, --shell          output config var in shell format

Example:

    $ heroku config:get RAILS_ENV
    production
helpLine: display a config value for an app

commands.description: display the config vars for an app
commands.help:
Usage: heroku config [flags]

display the config vars for an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 -s, --shell          output config vars in shell format
 --json               output config vars in json format
helpLine: display the config vars for an app

commands.description: set one or more config vars
commands.help:
Usage: heroku config:set [flags]

set one or more config vars

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Examples:

    $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging
    Setting config vars and restarting example... done, v10
    RAILS_ENV: staging
    
    $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging RACK_ENV=staging
    Setting config vars and restarting example... done, v11
    RAILS_ENV: staging
    RACK_ENV:  staging
helpLine: set one or more config vars

commands.help:

commands.help:
Usage: heroku domains [flags]

list domains for an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --json               output in json format

Example:

    $ heroku domains
    === example Heroku Domain
    example.herokuapp.com
    
    === example Custom Domains
    Domain Name      DNS Record Type  DNS Target
    ───────────      ───────────────  ──────────
    www.example.com  CNAME            www.example.herokudns.com

Usage: heroku domains:remove HOSTNAME [flags]

remove domain from an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

commands.help:

Flags:

 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

enables an app feature

Flags:

 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

commands.description: add an SSH key for a user
commands.help:
Usage: heroku keys:add [KEY] [flags]

add an SSH key for a user

Flags:
 -y, --yes  automatically answer yes for all prompts

if no KEY is specified, will try to find ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

Examples:

    $ heroku keys:add
    Could not find an existing public key.
    Would you like to generate one? [Yn] y
    Generating new SSH public key.
    Uploading SSH public key /.ssh/id_rsa.pub... done

    $ heroku keys:add /my/key.pub
    Uploading SSH public key /my/key.pub... done
helpLine: add an SSH key for a user

commands.description: remove all SSH keys for current user
commands.help:
Usage: heroku keys:clear

remove all SSH keys for current user
helpLine: remove all SSH keys for current user

commands.help:
Usage: heroku keys [flags]

display your SSH keys

Flags:
 -l, --long  display full SSH keys
 --json      output in json format

commands.description: remove an SSH key from the user
commands.help:
Usage: heroku keys:remove KEY

remove an SSH key from the user

Example:

    $ heroku keys:remove email@example.com
    Removing email@example.com SSH key... done
helpLine: remove an SSH key from the user

commands.help:
Usage: heroku notifications [flags]

display notifications

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --all                view all notifications (not just the ones for the current
                      app)
 --json               output in json format
 --read               show notifications already read

Usage: heroku ps [TYPE [TYPE ...]] [flags]

list dynos for an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --json               display as json

Examples:

    $ heroku ps
    === run: one-off dyno
    run.1: up for 5m: bash
    
    === web: bundle exec thin start -p $PORT
    web.1: created for 30s
    
    $ heroku ps run # specifying types
    === run: one-off dyno
    run.1: up for 5m: bash

Usage: heroku ps:restart [DYNO] [flags]

restart app dynos

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:restart web.1
    Restarting web.1 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:restart web
    Restarting web dynos... done

    $ heroku ps:restart
    Restarting dynos... done

Usage: heroku dyno:restart [DYNO] [flags]

restart app dynos

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:restart web.1
    Restarting web.1 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:restart web
    Restarting web dynos... done

    $ heroku ps:restart
    Restarting dynos... done

Usage: heroku restart [DYNO] [flags]

restart app dynos

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:restart web.1
    Restarting web.1 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:restart web
    Restarting web dynos... done

    $ heroku ps:restart
    Restarting dynos... done

commands.description: scale dyno quantity up or down
commands.help:
Usage: heroku ps:scale [flags]

scale dyno quantity up or down

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
    Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

    $ heroku ps:scale
    web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X
helpLine: scale dyno quantity up or down

commands.description: scale dyno quantity up or down
commands.help:
Usage: heroku dyno:scale [flags]

scale dyno quantity up or down

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
    Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

    $ heroku ps:scale
    web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X
helpLine: scale dyno quantity up or down

commands.help:

Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

commands.help:
Usage: heroku ps:stop DYNO [flags]

stop app dyno

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

Usage: heroku dyno:stop DYNO [flags]

stop app dyno

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

Usage: heroku ps:kill DYNO [flags]

stop app dyno

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

Usage: heroku dyno:kill DYNO [flags]

stop app dyno

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

Usage: heroku stop DYNO [flags]

stop app dyno

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

Usage: heroku kill DYNO [flags]

stop app dyno

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

stop app dyno or dyno type

Examples:

    $ heroku ps:stop run.1828
    Stopping run.1828 dyno... done

    $ heroku ps:stop run
    Stopping run dynos... done

Usage: heroku ps:type [flags]

manage dyno sizes

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

Usage: heroku ps:resize [flags]

manage dyno sizes

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

Usage: heroku resize [flags]

manage dyno sizes

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

Usage: heroku dyno:type [flags]

manage dyno sizes

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

Usage: heroku dyno:resize [flags]

manage dyno sizes

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

commands.description: display the releases for an app
commands.help:
Usage: heroku releases [flags]

display the releases for an app

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -n, --num NUM        number of releases to show
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 --json               output releases in json format

Example:

    $ heroku releases
    === example Releases
    v1 Config add FOO_BAR email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
    v2 Config add BAR_BAZ email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
    v3 Config add BAZ_QUX email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
helpLine: display the releases for an app

commands.description: view detailed information for a release
commands.help:
Usage: heroku releases:info [RELEASE] [flags]

view detailed information for a release

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use
 -s, --shell          output in shell format
 --json               output in json format
helpLine: view detailed information for a release

commands.help:
Usage: heroku releases:output [RELEASE] [flags]

View the release command output

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

Usage: heroku releases:rollback [RELEASE] [flags]

rollback to a previous release

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

If RELEASE is not specified, it will rollback one release

Usage: heroku rollback [RELEASE] [flags]

rollback to a previous release

Flags:
 -a, --app APP        app to run command against
 -r, --remote REMOTE  git remote of app to use

If RELEASE is not specified, it will rollback one release
